Participants were also asked to complete prospective illness diaries on any day of respiratory illness including symptoms and daily temperature measurements (thermometers provided by the study). At a baseline autumn/early winter visit, conducted by a research nurse from the practice, participants were trained in study procedures including how to complete study questionnaires, how to measure body temperature and how and when to take and submit nasal swabs. The study provided no medical advice as to what participants should do if ill, simply stating at recruitment that they should continue to use medical services as normal.
Recruitment was increased during the pandemic by including additional participants who did not provide blood samples and were not visited by a research nurse.

Participants were asked to self-sample on the second day of illness by taking a posterior nasal swab sample from each nostril. These samples were requested for all episodes of respiratory illness during follow up although in the first year (2006/7) swabbing was restricted to weeks when influenza was known to be circulating. Both swabs were placed in a vial of viral transport medium and returned in pre-paid packaging (which complied with the UN 3373 regulation) provided by the Health Protection Agency (HPA) with instructions to return specimens by post to the HPA Colindale laboratory as previously described for national surveillance samples. 1, 2 Sample handling and routine molecular testing Nucleic acid was extracted from returned samples and analysed by real-time PCR at the HPA Colindale lab as described previously. [3] [4] [5] [6] Briefly, the total nucleic acid from 150 ul of each sample was extracted using an automated extractor and used to prepare random hexamer-primed cDNA for respiratory virus PCR testing. Unused material from both original samples and extracted total nucleic acid were stored at -80°C with unused cDNA being stored at -20°C. All samples were routinely screened by real-time PCR for influenza A (subtypes H1, H3 and from 2009 onwards A(H1N1)pdm09), influenza B, respiratory syncytial virus A and B and human metapneumovirus.

A venous blood sample was taken at the baseline and follow up visits. Blood samples for serological assays were not drawn from children under five years of age and were on a voluntary basis for children up to 16 years. Willingness to provide blood samples was a condition of participation in adults although during the 2009 pandemic an additional cohort was recruited for clinical and virological follow up without serological follow up.

Blood specimens were couriered to the laboratory where serum was separated from cellular components and stored at -20°C. Sera were screened at the HPA Colindale laboratory by haemagglutination inhibition assay using standard methods as described previously. 3 /08 were also used. Serum specimens were tested in a 2-fold serial dilution series with an initial dilution of 1:8 and ending at 1:1,024. Titres were expressed as a reciprocal of the highest serum dilution that fully prevented haemagglutination. Serum specimens with no reactivity in the first dilution (<8; considered negative) were assigned a titre of 4; serum specimens that showed titres >1,024 were assigned a numerical value of 1,024 for statistical analysis. Four-fold rises in titre (including those who had no reactivity in the first dilution on the baseline specimen and a titre of 16 in the follow up sample) in individuals who were not vaccinated between baseline and follow up samples were taken as indicative of infection.

Serology results were fed back to participants at the end of the study. PCR results were fed back at the end of the study (2006/7-2008/9) or a minimum of 3 weeks after submission (2009/10-2011/12) so as not to influence consultation behaviour.

Follow up time was divided into six periods corresponding to different influenza seasons: 2006/7, 2007/8, 2008/9 and 2010/11 winter seasons; pandemic summer wave (2009) and 2009/10 pandemic winter season. A season was defined by the first and last dates of influenza isolation from the cohort. Each weekly illness diary was categorised into one of three mutually exclusive categories: Influenza-like illness with Fever >37.8°C (Cough and/or sore throat with fever of >37.8C); Influenza-like illness feeling feverish (Cough and/or sore throat, feels feverish but temperature ≤37.8°C); other respiratory illness not meeting these definitions. Respiratory illness episodes were defined by periods of continuous weekly illness and the maximum level of illness was mapped to the first week of each illness episode. Where participants stopped submitting weekly reports before the end of the season person time was censored on the date of receipt of the last report.

To allow comparison to the England population all Poisson analyses of rates were weighted by the inverse of the household size (as the sampling method would be expected to preferentially select larger households) and then post-stratified to the age/region structure of England each year. 9 Weekly rates are plotted expressed per 100,000 person-weeks for ease of comparison with surveillance data. Age standardised and age specific incidence rates per 100 person-seasons (as an estimate of the percentage of the population infected over a season) are calculated. For infection rates the time between bleeds during the influenza season is expressed as a proportion of the season's duration. For disease the total follow up time during the influenza season is expressed as a proportion of the season's duration. This methodology is chosen to allow comparison of rates during seasons of different duration and to account for differing person follow up time within seasons. An alternative approach whereby each season was assumed to last 5 months gave similar results (data not shown). We calculated rates and associated confidence intervals using Stata poisson regression commands with robust standard errors to acknowledge clustering at the level of GP practice (this also accounts for clustering at the individual and household level within practice).

We did not conduct follow up bleeds for participants recruited prior to the first (spring/summer) pandemic wave until after the second (winter) wave. Therefore we derived infection rates in the first wave according to the following methodology. We estimated the percent infected from the beginning of the first wave to the end of the second wave (by comparing age specific percentages of unvaccinated patients with antibodies (titre ≥32) to A(H1N1)pdm09 from the baseline specimens of 2008 participants (pre-pandemic) to the percentage positive after the winter wave of the pandemic). We then subtracted the direct measurements of the percentage infected during the second wave (based on data from those individuals recruited after the first wave) to give estimates of infection over the summer wave. Underreporting of illness may affect the observed attributable rate (e.g. if 85% of illnesses are reported in both those infected and those not infected, then the observed attributable rate will be 85% of the true attributable rate). Sensitivity analyses therefore estimated an adjusted attributable rate (ARa) by inflating the observed attributable rate (ARo) by the observed level of underreporting (based on the proportion (p) of expected weekly illness status reports received during periods of influenza circulation. ARa=ARo*(1/p) The rate of PCR confirmed disease in seroconverters was calculated as a measure of how often infection led to confirmed disease. As not all clinical cases would be expected to be PCR confirmed we also estimated the proportion of seroconversions leading to clinical illness (attributable risk) by calculating the difference in illness rate per 100 person-seasons between seroconverters and non seroconverters using Stata Epitab commands. This aims to measure the age adjusted rate of influenza attributable illness accounting for the fact that some illnesses in seroconverters will be attributable to other viruses.

To explore potential for bias introduced by some participants taking part in more than one season we conducted sensitivity analyses comparing the overall serologic infection rate and the overall PCR rate with returning participants included to rates with these participants included only in their first season of follow up. The rates were the same although with marginally wider confidence intervals due to the smaller numbers. Serologic infection rates: 18%, 95% CI 16-22% vs. 18%, 95% CI 15-21%. PCR positive rate 4%, 95% CI 3-5% vs. 4% 95% CI 3-6.

The numbers of letters sent by practices was monitored in season 1 as all letters were printed by the core study team and passed on to general practices for sending. In this season letters were sent to 2300 households and 243 households (602 individuals) agreed to participate. The response rate was not monitored in subsequent seasons as practices were responsible for printing and sending letters and not all practices returned data on the numbers of letters sent.

In seasons 3 to 6 previous participants were asked to participate again if the practice was still taking part in the study. Of the 1381 participants from seasons 1 and 2 22.7% (313) also participated in season 3, 25.7% (355) in season 4, 23.9% (330) in season 5 and 3.3% (46) in season 6. The percentage of participants who had previously taken part in Flu Watch was: 0% (0/602) in season 1; 0% (0/779) in season 2; 42.9% (313/729) in season 3; 93.7% (747/797) in season four (the summer wave of the pandemic); 17.8% (631/3552) in season five (the winter wave of the pandemic) and 20.5% (185/901) in season 6. Figure S1 shows number of participants enrolled in Flu Watch each week. Participants from the 2008/9 season continued to be followed up during the summer wave of the pandemic and recruitment was stepped up for the pandemic winter wave. Table S1 shows person follow up time and number of clinical events during follow up and Tables S2-S5 show rates of infection and PCR confirmed disease for different strain types and seasons.

When examining 72 unvaccinated participants who had a positive influenza A PCR result from a sample taken after the baseline serology bleed and at least 2 weeks before the follow up serology we found 63 (87.5%) of these had a 4 fold titre rise, 1 (1.39%) had a two-fold titre rise and 8 (11.11%) had no titre rise. This is similar to a recent report showing around 80% of PCR positives having a 4 fold rise. 10 The severity comparison of H3N2 and A(H1N1)pdm 2009 is based on PCR positive cases primarily from the 2008/9 H3N2 season and the winter seasons of 2009/10 and 20010/11 (A(H1N1)pdm2009) In table S1 we can see that the proportion of expected illness surveys completed (person weeks illness records/person weeks) did not change over these time periods : 2008/9 11158/12315 = 91%; 2009/10 46370/4960 = 94%; 2010/11 16326/17554 = 93%). We therefore have no evidence to suggest that changes in underreporting would have biased these estimates of the comparative severity of H3N2 and A(H1N1)pdm2009.

We searched published work to address four key questions relevant to our study: 1) what proportion of the population have influenza infection each influenza season, 2) what proportion of infections lead to illness, 3) what are the symptom profiles and severity of these illnesses and 4) what proportion of these illnesses lead to consultation. These questions require community-level prospective follow-up of individuals to allow the full spectrum of influenza cases (from asymptomatic infection to infections causing illness of varying severity) to be ascertained arising from a known population-level denominator, unbiased by vaccination or consultation. In order to identify relevant literature for all 4 questions, we reviewed historical community cohort studies of respiratory infections such as the Tecumseh study, the methods of which were adapted for the Flu Watch study. These studies are summarized by Monto. 11 We also reviewed findings from more recent cohort studies using similar designs. [12] [13] [14] [15] We then did 3 separate systematic literature searches in Embase, Global Health and Medline databases (up to 13 August 2013) to identify community-level cohort studies of influenza with PCR and/or Serological confirmation (see supplemental appendix for search terms).

Determination of population-level influenza infection rates (both symptomatic and asymptomatic cases) ideally requires pre-and post-season "paired" blood samples in the same individuals (to identify 4-fold rises in antibody titre) and determination of vaccination status (to rule out antibody titre rises that could be due to vaccination and not natural infection). To identify work relevant, we reviewed a recent review and meta-analysis of age-specific cumulative incidence for the 2009 influenza pandemic. 16 We also searched published work for community-level cohort studies of influenza that collected paired sera (see strategy 1 in search terms paragraph). Studies were included in this review if they were community-level cohorts but excluded if they only focused sub-sections of the population. For question 2 we additionally excluded studies that did not have prospective follow-up of respiratory illnesses. In addition to the studies meeting eligibility criteria we also comment on other study types which provide less direct estimates. For example, these include the case-ascertained studies in which households are recruited after and index case is identified through medical services, human challenge studies and mathematical models.

To add to the work identified for questions 1 and 2, we did a further 2 systematic literature searches in the same databases to identify relevant community-level prospective cohort studies that had PCR-confirmation of influenza illnesses (see strategies 2 and 3 in search terms paragraph). Studies were included if they were community-level cohorts with prospective follow-up of respiratory illnesses with swabbing for PCR confirmation of influenza. Studies were excluded if they only focused on sub-sections of the population or if they only did PCRs on a subset of illnesses (i.e. only consulting illnesses or only those meeting a case definition which would exclude less severe influenza).

We found on average 19% of the population were infected with influenza in seasonal years with decreasing risk of infection by age. Similar seasonal influenza infection levels were identified in historical studies from the United States, but these were confined to households with children. 11 These seasonal infection rates are also similar to those measured in rural Vietnam despite markedly different climate, seasonality and social conditions. 12 We found similar infection rates (18%) with highest rates in children during the 2009 pandemic. Other community studies measuring 2009 pandemic infection rates from paired sera are almost exclusively confined to South East Asia, and show similar levels of infection. [13] [14] [15] 17, 18 A meta-analysis of age specific cumulative incidence for the 2009 pandemic from 19 countries (mainly based on comparing population antibody prevalence before and after the pandemic rather than on paired sera from the same individuals) showed a similar overall age standardized rate of 21% with highest rates in children. 16, 19 This figure excluded US and Norway where high vaccination rates distorted results. We show that the 2010/11 pandemic wave was the only season in our study when the highest infection rates were in young adults but found no other community studies using paired sera in countries that experienced this third wave. Infection rates from previous pandemics are largely missing or are limited in interpretation due to large vaccination campaigns. 20 In England a study comparing population serological profiles before and after the first wave of the 2009 pandemic estimated that in London and the West Midlands 21.3% of children younger than 5 years of age, 42.0% of 5-14-year-olds, and 20.6% of 15-24-yearolds were infected with no evidence of infection in older age groups. 7 In other regions, only children younger than 15 years showed a significant increase from baseline (6.3%). Later work showed an increase in serologically defined infection in young adults in the third pandemic wave (2010/11) in England. 21 The consistency of findings from Flu Watch, from historical studies of seasonal influenza in temperate climates and from studies of seasonal and pandemic influenza in South East Asia suggests that frequent influenza infection (affecting in the region of a fifth of the population each year) with highest rates in children is an international phenomenon that is likely generalizable across settings. Whilst infection rates were similar in the 2009 pandemic compared to seasonal periods the lack of data from previous pandemics means we need to be cautious in generalizing to other previous or future pandemics.
body_text.section: 1) What proportion of the population has influenza infection each influenza season?

body_text.text: We estimated that 23% of seroconverters had a respiratory illness attributable to their infection and 25% of seroconverters were PCR positive. We found no significant difference by age or influenza strain although had limited power to assess age or strain specific differences in this. The historical Tecumseh study estimated that 15-25% of H3N2 and 19-34% of Influenza B infections lead to clinical disease. 22 In Vietnam 14% of seasonal H1N1, 11% H3N2, 15% of influenza B and 16% of A(H1N1)pdm2009 led to influenza-like-illness (defined as a respiratory illness with fever of 38°C or higher and either a cough or a sore throat). 12 However, the figures from Vietnam likely underestimate the proportion experiencing respiratory illness as milder cases without fever were excluded (in Flu Watch these accounted for 46% of PCR confirmed cases). The percentage of seroconverting and non-seroconverting adults with acute respiratory illnesses during the 2009 pandemic has been reported from community cohorts in Singapore and Hong Kong. 13, 15 From these we calculate an attributable risk of 30% and 25% respectively and 25% for children (0-18 years). A Hong Kong study which followed up families who had a medically attended index case of seasonal or 2009 pandemic influenza found that among 19 secondary household infections, 12 (63%) of them developed an acute respiratory illness and 11 (58%) tested PCR positive. 23 Small numbers, however, limit interpretation. A recent modelling study has suggested that 25% of seasonal H1N1 infections and 35% of H3N2 infections lead to illness. 24 Human challenge studies, which are mainly limited to participants with low or no measurable baseline antibody and use nasal administration of virus in high doses, show around 67% of infected become ill. 25 This, however becomes considerably lower for those with detectable baseline antibodies (>1/24) where 15% of those infected became ill. Taken as a whole this evidence supports our finding that the majority of influenza infections do not lead to illness.
body_text.section: 2) What proportion of infections lead to illness?

body_text.text: Flu Watch found that only 46% of PCR confirmed cases of influenza had a fever greater than 37.8°C and therefore most would not meet the CDC clinical case definition for Influenza-Like-Illness. Additionally, we found that PCR-confirmed A(H1N1)pdm09 cases were less severe than PCR-confirmed H3N2 cases when it came to feeling feverish, muscle aches, runny nose, blocked nose and sneezing. Unlike the Flu Watch study, many community level studies do not have prospective symptom follow-up and virological investigation of all respiratory illnesses rather than just those meeting the ILI case definition. A recent community cohort study of Hutterite communities in Canada which did collect this data found that overall 36% of PCR confirmed cases reported fever. 26 They also found that fever, cough and runny nose appeared to be more frequent symptoms of H3N2 illnesses compared to other influenza A or B strains. A Hong Kong study reported on illness profiles in 7 PCR confirmed secondary household cases of A(H1N1)pdm09 and 4 PCR confirmed secondary household cases of H3N2 and found that 45% had fever ≥37.8ºC. 27 Historical studies in Tecumseh, Michigan found that among culture confirmed seasonal influenza A and B illnesses, 71% of those aged less than 20 years and 56% of those aged 20 years and older developed fever. 22 The Tecumseh studies also reports that H3N2 illnesses are generally more severe than H1N1. Influenza related excess mortality in the United States is higher during seasons of H3N2 circulation which also suggests that H3N2 is generally more severe than H1N1 infection. 28 Our study is the first to show that H1N1pmd09 was less severe than seasonal H3N2 influenza, although there are reports that H3N2 is the more severe of the seasonal influenza strains.
body_text.section: 3) What are the symptom profiles and severity of these illnesses?

body_text.text: There is some information on the proportion of people with influenza-like-illnesses (ILI) that consult medical services, 29 however ILI is neither specific nor sensitive case definition and therefore is not the best indication of the consulting behaviour of influenza illnesses. Flu Watch study is one of the few community level cohort studies with prospective symptom recording, virological testing of all respiratory illnesses and information on medical consultations. We found that 17% of PCR-confirmed influenza cases consulted for their illness. It is notable that even in a country with universal free access to health care, the proportion of people with influenza illnesses consulting medical services is still very low. A recent (2010/11) household cohort study in Michigan found that 32% of the 130 PCR-confirmed influenza cases sought medical attention (38% among children and 16% among adults). 30 The historic Tecumseh study found that among those aged less than 20 years and those aged 20 and above, 38% and 41% respectively of culture positive cases consulted a physician for their illnesses. 22 Propensity to consult is likely to vary according to cultural norms and service availability.
body_text.section: 4) What proportion of influenza illnesses lead to consultation?

body_text.text: Measures of community disease burden will increase the validity of population models that are widely used to infer the effectiveness and cost effectiveness of countermeasures such as use of antivirals, vaccines and behavioural interventions.
